channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Perl for High Performance; Senior Developer, London
item.description: Do you know how to solve problems in terms of queues and caches? Does the idea of truly scaling your architecture on AWS excite you? Not fazed by designing your workloads to be distributed?

item.title: Perl Developer who wants to learn Scala and NodeJS - West London
item.description: Love Perl but want to skill-up on another stack at your employerâ€™s expense?

MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: September 2018 Grant Votes
item.description: Both Future::AsyncAwait (6,256 USD) and MoarVM JIT Compiler Expression Backend Maturation (7,000 USD) were funded!

item.title: What is SQL injection?
item.description: Do we need to be told about this even now? Well read it as a refresher. It is presented very well.

item.title: How Postgres is more than a relational database: Extensions
item.description: Craig takes us through how Postgres has shifted itself from simply a relational database to more of a data platform.

item.title: Deconstructing Map, Filter, and Reduce
item.description: Joel Thoms explains Javascript features in short and simple language.

item.title: namespace::local above, below, and around
item.description: Short and precise description of namespace::local by none other than the creator himself, Konstantin Uvarin.

item.title: The Perl Renaming Debate Highlights Tensions
item.description: Nikos Vaggalis takes us in the past and shares what people thought about it then. A very interesting insights into the debate. Highly recommended.

item.title: namespace::local: hiding utility functions in moo[se] roles
item.description: Konstantin, again showing us the fun use of namespace::local and don't forget to read the comment below by Toby Inkster.

item.title: Monthly Report - November
item.description: Time for monthly report, quick recap by me.

item.title: Security Sprint: using Seccomp for secure containers
item.description: If you are into Docker and want to keep it secure then you must read this. Highly recommended.

item.title: An Introduction into Spacemacs from a Vim user
item.description: A quick introduction to Spacemacs.

item.title: Rakudo.js mini update - Firefox support
item.description: Pawel shares the news Rakudo.js supports for native JavaScript big integers.

item.title: JS Foundation and Node.js Foundation Progress Towards Merger
item.description: Ian shares the joint announcement of a planned merger and community feedback approving the intent, the boards of the JS Foundation and the Node.js Foundation are in what they call a â€œbootstrapâ€ phase, exploring all of the potential details that must be considered as part of a merger.

item.description: StickerYou doesnâ€™t only allow you to make custom stickers for your business. You can also brand your staff with custom name badges. Itâ€™s an easy way to tie it all together, amplifying your brand identity and letting your customers know youâ€™re there to help. StickerYou.com allows you to order any size, shape and quantity. What are you waiting for? Get your team better gear for the new year! Use code PERL10 at checkout for an exclusive Perl Weekly discount.

item.title: #384 - Perl Advent Calendar
item.description:
Hi there

With start of December, I see flood of Advent Calendars for the first time ever. It could be I was ignorant before. It is never too late though. I am sure, every Perl hacker would have come across of at least one Advent Calendar i.e. Perl Advent Calendar. For the first time, I came across Mojolicious Advent Calendar. There is one for Perl 6 as well. There is even one for Perl 6 one liner Advent Calendar, thanks to Andrew Shitov. I admire all the people behind these Advent Calendar phenomena. It is lot of fun as I tried it myself for the very first time and contributed to Perl Advent Calendar 2018. It would be a proud moment for me when it does show up one day. I would like to encourage newcomer to come forward and contribute as well to their choice of Advent Calendars. If you missed it this year for any reason then make sure you be prepared well in time next year.

Last week we had London Perl Workshop 2018, if you have attended the event then don't forget to submit the survey. All registered attendees should have received an email from Barbie with link to the survey. Please do share your views about the talks and the events in general. It would help the event organisers to hold the workshop better next time.

Join The DC and Baltimore PM groups for a workshop in Silver Spring, Maryland on Saturday, April 6, 2019. They are accepting talks until Jan 1, 2019 and registration is open! The workshop aims to teach fun real-world usage of Perl and related technologies. Find out more at here.

Have fun reading this week newsletter
